Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Impacts of El Niño-Southern oscillation on Indian Ocean heat waves
Award.AbstractNarration:
Abrupt changes in sea surface temperature (SST) are known to disrupt fishery productivity and marine ecosystem functioning by affecting the survival and distribution of many commercially important marine species. A recent ocean heat wave in 2011 occurred off Western Australia and caused unprecedented warming in the southeast Indian Ocean. Understanding the causes and frequency of these extreme warming events are of particular interest to societal and marine sectors due to their adverse consequences. The frequency of Indian Ocean heat waves will be addressed in collaboration with Dr. Matthew England from the University of New South Wales in Australia. This project will use a unique combination of statistical and state-of-the-art climate models to quantify changes in the frequency of ocean heat waves in relation to the decadal variability of the El Niño-Southern Oscillation (ENSO). Dr. England is a noted climate expert in this region and has made significant contributions towards understanding the variability of SST in the Indian Ocean.

This project will model El Niño teleconnection patterns in the equatorial Pacific with the spatial extent of extreme warming events in the Indian Ocean using Bayesian statistics coupled with global circulation model experiments. Much of the variance in Indian Ocean SST can be explained by ENSO-induced teleconnection patterns that manifest in the tropical Pacific Ocean. This suggests that Indian Ocean heat waves are not stochastic phenomena, but are rather modulated by a forced response due to ENSO. The transient interactions between ENSO teleconnections and extreme SST in the Indian Ocean are not completely understood, and the emergence of new, coupled climate models justifies the need for examining changes in climate variability and extreme oceanographic events. This NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with the Australian Academy of Science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Ocean heatwaves are relatively new phenomena (first described in 2011) that are characteristic of abrupt, large-scale and persistent patterns of extreme sea surface temperatures. These events are often regionally unprecedented and have detrimental consequences to both marine ecosystems and fishing industries. It is very likely that the mean long-term warming trend and climate change have fueled ocean heatwaves in the past, and this makes studying their underlying drivers timely and important. This EAPSI project examined the anomaly properties of ocean heatwaves in the Southern Hemisphere and their links to large-scale climate patterns. To begin to understand the climatic and synoptic-scale drivers of ocean heatwaves, this project makes an effort to identify regions in the Southern Hemisphere where these events are most likely to occur and explores climate teleconnection patterns associated with re-occurring events.

 

High spatial and temporal resolution sea surface temperature (SST) and reanalysis products make it possible to identify ocean heatwaves using observational datasets. The PI implemented an extremes metric that considers both the intensity and duration of SST anomalies. Anomaly maps and area-averaged time series of heatwave “hotspots” regions allow the spatial and temporal frequencies of ocean heatwaves to be compared to climate modes, including the El Niño-Southern Oscillation, Indian Ocean Dipole and Southern Annular Mode. The synchronous pattern of ocean heatwaves in the Southern Hemisphere extratropics suggest that there is a common driver of SST extremes that may be related to dominant large-scale modes of climate variability. Furthermore, composites of atmospheric and oceanic conditions during ocean heatwaves show the physical synoptic-scale properties that conspire to produce these events.

 

Ocean heatwave research will continue to be a valuable investment for the benefits of societal and marine sectors. Results of this project have been disseminated to ecologist, oceanographers and climate scientists alike, and the project has supported active and fruitful research collaborations between the U.S. and Australia.
